title: Is it a red flag that the man I am dating won't speak to me over an NFL game?
opening_message: I'm struggling with feeling like I've done something wrong in our relationship because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost a big game against mine.

all.1: I'm still in the early stages of dating and we haven't officially discussed exclusivity.

turns.content: I'm struggling with feeling like I've done something wrong in our relationship because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost a big game against mine.

It sounds like this loss has really gotten under his skin, and it's understandable that he might be taking it out on you. It can be tough when we're passionate about something and it doesn't go our way. Can you tell me more about what's been going on since the game - has he said anything specific to you that's making you feel like you've done something wrong?
"I just feel so abandoned, like I'm not even worth a conversation anymore. It's like, I get that we didn't win, but can't he at least try to understand why I was so upset?"

used_shard.text: He's stopped talking to me altogether after the game, saying he won't talk until he's ready.

turns.content: It sounds like this loss has really affected your emotional connection with him, and you're feeling unheard and unseen right now. That must be really tough for you. You're not just looking for a conversation, but also some validation that your feelings are important to him too. Have you tried reaching out to him directly about how you're feeling, or are you feeling stuck on what to say?
"I don't know, doc...part of me wants to just tell him how I'm really feeling, but another part of me is worried that I'll come across as needy or demanding."

used_shard.text: I'm torn between sharing my feelings with him now or waiting until he's ready to talk again.

turns.content: It sounds like you're feeling a bit stuck between being honest about your emotions and not wanting to "rock the boat". That's a tough spot to be in! You want to express yourself, but also don't want to make things worse. Have you considered having an open conversation with him about how this silence is affecting you, without necessarily focusing on his team's loss or win?
"I don't know, man... I just wanted to celebrate with him, but that vibe was like a bucket of ice water on my enthusiasm. Now it feels like even mentioning the win might be too much."

used_shard.text: His reaction has ruined my enjoyment of our team's victory and made me feel sad and disconnected from the person I want to talk to.

turns.content: I totally get it! It sounds like your excitement and celebration were met with a chill instead, and now you're hesitant to bring it up again. That must be really disappointing for you. Can you tell me more about what you hope would happen if you did talk to him about it? Would you want him to apologize or just listen to how you feel?

"I guess I'd want him to just understand where I'm coming from and acknowledge my feelings, you know? But deep down, I'm scared that it's not just about this one instance, and he's going to see me as some needy guy who can't handle a little disappointment."

used_shard.text: I'm worried that if we were in a relationship, this kind of pouty behavior would be a recurring problem.

turns.content: It sounds like there's a deeper fear lurking beneath the surface - the fear of being seen as needy or clingy. That can be really tough to shake off! You're not just wanting him to understand your feelings, but also to see you in a certain way. Have you ever had conversations with him where he's made you feel like you're being too sensitive or emotional?

Yeah, actually, yeah... He has told me I'm overreacting before, that I need to "toughen up" or just "get over it". It's like, I don't know, it makes me feel like my emotions aren't valid or something.

used_shard.text: I feel ridiculous for thinking this is an issue, but his behavior seems petty and childish.

turns.content: That sounds really invalidating and frustrating! When someone tells you to "toughen up" or "get over it", it can come across as dismissive of your feelings, right? It's like they're minimizing the emotional impact that event had on you. Have you ever felt like he just doesn't get you or understand what you're going through?

"Exactly, it feels like he's not taking me seriously or considering how his words are impacting me. I'm torn between bringing it up with him now and waiting for him to come around, which is making me feel anxious and uncertain about our relationship."

used_shard.text: I'm unsure if I should address this issue now or wait for him to come around, but it's affecting my mood and feelings about us.

turns.content: It sounds like you're caught in a bit of limbo, unsure of what to do next. You want to address the issue, but you're also worried about how he'll react or respond. That uncertainty can be really stressful! Have you thought about what your non-negotiables are in terms of how you want to be treated and respected in this relationship?
"I guess I'm just worried about being rejected or hurt if I bring it up, but at the same time, I don't want to be stuck in a situation where I'm not on the same page as her."

used_shard.text: I'm still in the early stages of dating and we haven't officially discussed exclusivity.

turns.content: It sounds like you're weighing the risks of speaking up against the potential consequences of staying silent. You're trying to navigate this tricky situation and prioritize your own emotional well-being. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "being on the same page" in a relationship? What does that look like for you, and how do you think it would impact your connection with him?

"Honestly, I feel like we're just trying to keep the peace and avoid conflicts, even if it means not fully being on the same page. And yeah, the distance makes everything harder - sometimes it feels like we're just going through the motions instead of really connecting."

used_shard.text: We're in a long-distance relationship and that affects our communication and interactions.

turns.content: It sounds like you're feeling a sense of disconnection and superficiality in your relationship, like you're just maintaining the status quo rather than truly connecting with each other. The distance can definitely exacerbate that feeling of being disconnected. Do you think there are some small, everyday things you could do to help bridge that gap and feel more connected despite the physical distance?

"I guess what's surprising me is that even when we're apart and there's no pressure or competition between us, I still feel like we can connect on a deeper level. It's like our relationship isn't just about winning or losing, you know?"

used_shard.text: His football team lost to mine, but I didn't rub it in because I respect him as a person.

turns.content: I love that! It sounds like you're discovering a sense of freedom and authenticity in your relationship when you're not feeling pressured or competitive. That's really beautiful! When you do get to spend time together, what are some things that you enjoy doing together that make you feel more connected and relaxed?

Honestly, when we're just chillin' together, I really enjoy playing video games with her - it's something we can both geek out about and just be ourselves. And, weirdly enough, cooking dinner together feels pretty great too; it's like our own little dance where we work together without feeling like we're in a competition.

turns.content: That sounds amazing! It's great that you've found common ground in gaming and cooking that allows you to relax and be yourselves around each other. Those moments of shared pleasure can really bring people closer together. What is it about those activities that makes them feel so special and enjoyable for you? Is there something specific that stands out, like the sense of teamwork or the joy of creating something together?
